node.text:
Ok, I know I know - this may be one of those kinda-eye-roll-moments, the “Wait I can't tell my daughter she’s pretty?”

I am not trying to prescribe what you can or can’t say - truly. And without a doubt, dropping a “You look beautiful!” here and there - no damage done! My IGTV explores a larger point: what is body confidence after all and where does it come from? And how might comments about a child’s appearance do more to diminish than build body confidence?

I know, I know, it sounds very confusing and almost paradoxical. That’s why I encourage you to check out this video - I kept it short at 2 minutes, so it’s very do-able. Clearly there’s more to say which is why I can’t wait for you all to jot your reactions and thoughts into comments!

node.title: Why I Don’t Comment On My Kid’s Appearance

node.text:
.
.
Tell me if this cycle feels familiar to you: you want to set a boundary - maybe it’s saying no to family wanting to visit or telling your kids you can’t host a playdate at your house… but instead of setting this boundary, you hear yourself saying yes. Then the resentment kicks in, either right away or later on.  Then a small thing set you off and there’s the reactivity, screaming, and rage.  Now let me be clear: there’s nothing wrong with you and I know this cycle isn’t enjoyable or intentional for any of us. 

And here’s the good news: this Boundary Struggle / Resentment / Rage cycle is *not* inevitable.  We can change it. And the change starts here: working on boundaries.

And here’s the even better news: Friday July 16 at 1230pm EST, I am holding a Zoom workshop that’ll give you concrete, actionable tools to change.  In Strengthening Boundaries, Reducing Parental Rage, I will teach you how to: set boundaries, tolerate pushback, cope with other’s disappointment, manage your own self-doubt, and develop consistency and self-assurance.

And maybe the best news: a ticket gives you access to the live workshop AND the recording. So if you can’t make it or might have to hop out early, no worries - the workshop will be there for you to watch over and over.

This is an important one.  Boundaries set us up for self-care, sturdy leadership, and the potential for relationships to actually feel enhancing and energizing, not depleting and enraging.

Don’t miss this workshop. It’s gonna be a good one. Link in bio or go to learning.goodinside.com

node.text:
Boundaries are not what we tell kids not to do; boundaries are what we tell kids we will do.

In this short and to-the-point IGTV, I make this important distinction to provide the framework for you to effectively set and hold boundaries with your kids.

Can’t wait to hear what you think.

node.text:
Preparing Your Kid For Camp

Camp is coming up. What can we do today to help our kids with the upcoming transition? After all, they are going from a year of staying in, being with the same small group, seeing their parents all the time… to camp, which may be filled with new kids, new activities, new separation. And if your kids are going to sleepaway camp, then the change is especially meaningful!

In this IGTV, I walk through 4 actionable steps you can do today to help your kids get ready - emotionally! - for camp. I model four strategies and share scripts that you can use in your home right away.

node.text:
I’m often asked about fake crying - why kids do it and how to respond. Well, I have a different take on fake crying… one in which we pause and consider what’s really happening underneath and what a child is looking for. 

We can all get into “invalidation cycles” with our kids (or other adults - or ourselves!) - a child worries her needs and feelings aren’t seen as real and so the expression escalates. This leads a parent to be more likely to invalidate what’s happening which then leads to further escalation… we can all see how this continues. 

In this IGTV, I rethink “fake crying” and offer a different framework that sees your child as a teammate, gets to the core of the issue, and leads to these types of tearful moments becoming less likely.

node.text:
We often have a choice with our kids - we can come down hard on their behavior or we can look out for a small win, for a moment that is slightly different, something that feels a bit more positive. 

I had this the other day in my home with my three year old, where I was caught between responding to my son with frustration or changing my perspective and seeing a small win. This IGTV is for all of us who get caught in negative cycles for our kids - and for all of us looking for a way out.

node.text:
There are so many things we want to teach our kids - not just math or reading but the most important things in life… how to deal with frustration, how to bounce back from failure, how to stick with hard things, how to manage tough emotions. And yet, so often, our kids shut down when we try to help… what’s a well-intentioned parent to do?

Well, here’s the thing. To learn, we have to be free of shame. Now, I’m not saying you’re causing shame in your child - I actually don’t think you are! And yet, shame comes from aloneness and otherness, and because kids are learning so many things that we seem to do with ease and capability… there is almost inherent aloneness in being a kid! 

In this IGTV, I walk through one of my all-time favorite do-as-often-as-possible parenting strategies, one that “deshames your house” so that you have more and more openings to connect with your kids and have them take in all the skills you want to teach them.

Can’t wait to hear what you think!

node.text:
We talk what to do when your kid compares herself, how to reply when your kid says “I’m fat,” screen time, managing food and snacks, and handling difficult behavior at school. 

Thank you to all of you who requested to pop in with a question! Loved this spontaneity!

node.text:
Ah….guilt. So many of us have inherited a version of guilt that… is actually the process of taking on other people’s feelings. 

In this IGTV, I walk through a way to understand what guilt really is and what it isn’t, and then share a powerful strategy to put this understanding into action. 

This short video will leave you rethinking guilt and feeling better equipped to take care of yourself, set boundaries, and make decisions that feel right for you.

If this video resonates and you’re excited about more opportunities to work on holding your boundaries (and therefore reduce the frequency of feeling guilt) my Reparenting Workshop is for you. Follow the link in my bio to learn more.

node.text:
Over and over we tell ourselves, “I’m going to be calm when my kid has a tantrum” or “It’s ok if my child doesn’t want to join soccer right away, I’ll stay calm” … and yet when these things happen, we find ourselves once again reacting, yelling, saying things we don’t want to say. Why? 

Ok, well here’s the most important thing: Nothing is wrong with you. You’re a good parent having a hard time and our curiosity is our most important trait here. 

Let’s be curious, without judgment or blame: “There must be something that happens for me… there must be something so big that it overpowers my desire to act in a different way… huh… that’s interesting…”

In this IGTV, I talk about why our kids trigger us AND what we can do about reducing our reactivity. This is one of the most important ideas in parenting - as we work on our own triggers, we can show up in the way that feels better to us, and without-a-doubt feels better to our kids as well.

node.text:
Your child is clinging to you at a soccer class… won’t join their friends at a birthday party… hides behind you at a family gathering. What’s going on here and what’s a parent to do?

In this IGTV, I reframe hesitation and shyness and give you a different way to think about what a child might need in these moments.  

If you often watch your child struggle to try new things or back away from challenges, follow the link in my bio to check out my Rethinking Confidence Workshop. Here I dive much deeper and offer many actionable strategies to build your child’s confidence and, likely, your own along the way. 

Can’t wait to hear your thoughts.

node.text:
There’s a lot of talk about the importance of validation when a child is upset - this may sound like “You’re so mad!” or “You’re really frustrated!”

And yet… sometimes it falls flat. Our kids don’t seem to connect to this approach or, worse, escalate further and seem angry as we name their feelings. You’re not “doing it wrong” and nothing is wrong with you or your child.

In this IGTV, I teach something different, something I call “Validate the Magnitude” - which so many kids absorb and respond to and seem to be *looking for* - the same kids who resist having their feelings named often respond well to this strategy. At the very least, it’s another tantrum-tool to have in your back pocket. 

And if you’re thinking “Ok I’m liking this strategy but I need more help!”... I’ve got you covered. My “Managing Meltdowns and Building Emotion Regulation” course gives you a framework and 15+ strategies for handling ... and reducing (!) meltdowns so that you feel more equipped as your family’s study leader. 

Let me know what you think.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Dr. Becky Kennedy | Parenting on July 23, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'PARENTING Truth You don't have to punish your child. A child who acts out needs boundaries, empathy, and skill-building- not consequences, criticism, and shame-building.'.

node.text:
Parenting with empathy, validation, and boundaries - rather than shame, punishment, and Time-Outs… this doesn’t make you soft. It makes you effective. You know that to get the best out of someone, you need to see the best in them.

Behaviorism has had a huge influence on parenting. What is behaviorism? Wikipedia defines it this way: “the theory that human and animal behavior can be explained in terms of conditioning, without appeal to thoughts or feelings, and that psychological disorders are best treated by altering behavior patterns.”

And yet, things like feeling good about ourselves, emotion regulation, intrinsic motivation, passion, compassion, empathy, resilience… none of these can be shaped through behavior. We can’t punish a child into managing tough feelings, making good decisions, caring about others, learning how to be in healthy relationships. Actually, punishment gets in the way of these critical developments - after all, punishments make kids feel bad inside, which leads to self-blame, dysregulation, and a belief that loving relationships involve power dynamics, fear, aloneness, and control. Not effective in the short-term or long-term.

Now, let me be clear - I am a BIG fan of boundaries. Boundaries are not punishment. Here’s an example after your child hits her brother. Punishment: “Go to your room, no TV tonight!” Boundaries: Step in, separate children, “I will NOT let you hit your brother.” To your son: “Wow, that hurt. I know. That was NOT ok.” To your daughter: “I know you’re upset about something. I care about that. We have to find other ways to express it.”

No punishment. No bad kids. No control. No fear of abandonment. Instead: safety, limits, seeing the good inside, connection, setting the stage for emotion regulation and skill building. Seems like a pretty good trade in my book.

If parenting with firm limits and without punishments is new to you, it makes sense you’d need a guide. This is exactly why I made my foundational course, Managing Meltdowns and Building Emotion Regulation. I walk you through how to be a sturdy effective parent without punishment, Time Outs, or sticker charts.

node.text:
If whining gets under your skin, join the club. We are in this together.

And yet if we consider why kids whine, we can respond more effectively. When whining, kids feel alone and unseen. When we respond with humor, we reconnect with our kids and show them generosity, which is what they’re looking for in the first place.

Try this “How’d those whines get in there?” technique today. Really act it out. Maybe after “getting” the whines, walk to a window and open it, pretend throw-out the whines, quickly shut the window to “keep the whines out.” Be playful. Be silly. Then move on. This also allows you to access your levity rather than frustration.

No this doesn’t reinforce whining. This helps regulate the disconnected feeling that leads to the whining, which reduces it over time.

If you find whining to be a major trigger for you, if you want to decrease yelling and reactivity in these moments, my Reparenting Workshop is for you. Follow the link in my bio or head to learning.goodinside.com to watch the preview.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Dr. Becky Kennedy | Parenting on July 21, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Want your kid to become an independent problem-solver? Stop dictating, start collaborating. Swipe to see the difference'.

node.text:
Parenting is exhausting. It really is. For me too. And it’s even more exhausting when we are in problem-solving mode for our kids: we are the ones picking up their bath towels and hanging them up every day, we are clearing their dishes for then, we are telling them how to treat their little sibling, we are lecturing them about being patient.

Here’s the thing: we can make parenting slightly less exhausting. And every little bit of energy we as parents can reclaim for ourselves is worth it and can change a day from feeling impossible to feeling merely challenging.  This is a big difference.

The more we empower our kids to solve their own problems, the less we have to step in and do so much for them. This is true with small things like chores and big things like emotion regulation.  Now I am not suggesting a hands-off approach - for sure, we have a big role to play in helping our kids access their own independence and resilience.  And yet what’s also true is our kids won’t “get there” if we are doing the heavy lifting ourselves.

Let’s think of ourselves, in a job where we are less experienced than our manager.  How will you best learn to be productive and capable? From your managing telling you what to do… or from your manager connecting with you when times are tough and *scaffolding* your own learning by giving you just enough to figure out solutions on your own? To me this is the difference between saying yo a child, “40+60? Oh, it’s 100!” versus “40+60… hm… that’s tricky…. And I know you can figure this out” or maybe adding, “Well, I know you know what 4+6 is… so hm…” and then - and here’s the kicker - letting your child have that amazing “aha moment” in their own bodies. This is how kids feel capable, which is what generates the desire and ability to be independent.

Let’s start seeing our kids as people who need our support to find their own ideas and solutions - this is very different than providing our ideas and solutions.  Let’s empower our kids by collaborating, not dictating.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Dr. Becky Kennedy | Parenting on July 21, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Want your kid to become an independent problem-solver? Stop dictating, start collaborating. Swipe to see the difference'.

Photo by Dr. Becky Kennedy | Parenting on July 21, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'SITUATION 1 Your child is in a hitting phase. DICTATING: "You have to stop hitting your brother. When you're mad, just find me and tell me!" ........... COLLABORATING: "I'm thinking about how hard it is to play safely with your brother. You're not in trouble. Actually, think you re someone with great ideas. When you're frustrated... hm... wonder what you could do?"'.

Photo by Dr. Becky Kennedy | Parenting on July 21, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'SITUATION 2 Your child keeps forgetting to pick her clothes off her bedroom floor. DICTATING: "Write yourself a note and put it on your wall so you remember to pick up your clothes." .............. ............ COLLABORATING: "There's something about picking your clothes off the floor that's hard to remember. used to have a hard time with that too. There must be ways to make remembering easier... hm... let's brainstorm..."'.

node.text:
Kids are constantly learning new things—from using the potty to tying their shoes to tackling a math problem—and, as we all know, learning is hard. Sometimes, the frustration of not-knowing-yet leads kids to “I can't do it!" 

In this week's episode, I talk to three parents about how to help a child through these moments with actionable strategies and scripts. (Hint: It's all about building up a kid's frustration tolerance, not solving the problem for them.)

node.text:
Ok, I know I know - this may be one of those kinda-eye-roll-moments, the “Wait I can't tell my daughter she’s pretty?”

I am not trying to prescribe what you can or can’t say - truly. And without a doubt, dropping a “You look beautiful!” here and there - no damage done! My IGTV explores a larger point: what is body confidence after all and where does it come from? And how might comments about a child’s appearance do more to diminish than build body confidence?

I know, I know, it sounds very confusing and almost paradoxical. That’s why I encourage you to check out this video - I kept it short at 2 minutes, so it’s very do-able. Clearly there’s more to say which is why I can’t wait for you all to jot your reactions and thoughts into comments!

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Dr. Becky Kennedy | Parenting on July 16, 2021. May be an image of text that says '5 THINGS Words Your Inner Child Needs to Hear in Tough Moments Share these words first with yourself and then with your own children'.

node.text:
This list was community-generated. Yes, that’s right. YOU created this amazing resource.

Weeks ago, I asked you all what words you wish an adult had told you, when you were a child, in your hard times - when you were melting down, when you made a mistake, when you were dysregulated, when you were in a moment of struggle. Your answers poured in. You knew the words that you so desperately needed to hear.

If we didn’t get the validation and empathy we needed as kids, then an inner-child part of us is still waiting.  They’re looking to US, now, to share these words. And here’s the things: I’d bet our own kids need these words from us. We cannot give out what we are not actively giving in - we can’t show patience and compassion to our kids in their moments of struggle if we are not loading ourselves up with patience and compassion in our own moments of struggle. 

Intergenerational change doesn’t begin with our interactions with our kids. Intergenerational change begins with our interactions with ourselves - especially with the parts of ourselves that are still waiting to be seen, to be cared about, to be loved. We can do this, starting right now, with the words in this post. Find a slide that resonates with you. Pause on it. Place your feet on the ground. Place your hand over your heart. Say these words to yourself, to that part of you that needed these words decades ago and still needs them today. It’s normal to tear up as you do - these are the tears of relief from that child part of you that’s finally receiving what they’ve been yearning for… acknowledgement, connection, a message of goodness.

And then? Share these words with your child. You may be surprised that you don’t even have to remind yourself to do this - after all, when we start showing ourselves more self-compassion and self-care, it starts overflowing into all of our external relationships.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Dr. Becky Kennedy | Parenting on July 16, 2021. May be an image of text that says '5 THINGS Words Your Inner Child Needs to Hear in Tough Moments Share these words first with yourself and then with your own children'.
Photo by Dr. Becky Kennedy | Parenting on July 16, 2021. May be an image of text that says '1 "If it feels feels like a big deal, it is a big deal."'.
Photo by Dr. Becky Kennedy | Parenting on July 16, 2021. May be an image of text that says '2 "Everyone struggles. You are not your struggles and you are not alone."'.
Photo by Dr. Becky Kennedy | Parenting on July 16, 2021. May be an image of text that says '3 "Having big feelings doesn't make you too much."'.
Photo by Dr. Becky Kennedy | Parenting on July 16, 2021. May be an image of text that says '4 "You can tell me anything. There's g could do or not do that would make me stop loving you."'.
Photo by Dr. Becky Kennedy | Parenting on July 16, 2021. May be an image of text that says '5 "You don't have to be perfect to be loved."'.

node.text:
I used to be a people pleaser.

When I was younger, I took on the role of “good girl” - easy, flexible, a peace-maker.  No one explicitly told me, “Becky, pay attention to balancing the family system instead of balancing yourself.” Certainly no one ever said, “If you take care of your own wants and needs, you will be all alone!”

So what kind of messages did I pick up on? Tantrums were not received well.  I got positive attention for how well-behaved and mild-mannered I was.  I remember how good it felt to make my parents happy - with my behavior, my responsible decision making, my grades.

So what’s wrong here? What’s the problem? Well, when we learn to orient our gaze out - to pay attention to what we can do to get good feelings from others, what we can do to make others happy, what we can do to fulfill other people’s value systems… we lose ourselves.  We miss our on years of looking inward, developing our own true Self, and learning to assert our individual wants and needs.

To be clear, I’m not even saying my parents are the “bad guys” here.  In fact, let’s get away from the whole good/bad binary.  Here IS the essence of my story: Being a people-pleaser, while necessary and understandable and adaptive in childhood, no longer worked for me in adulthood.  I’m guessing it no longer works for many of you either.

This is why so many of us are filled with resentment and rage. We aren’t “angry people.” We are people who are emptied and unseen after years of caring for others at the expense of ourselves, after years of asking “Will I let them down?” instead of “Will I let myself down?,” after years of our energy flowing out instead of safeguarding energy for ourselves, learning even how to self-generate more.

It’s not too late. We can change. I know this - I have changed. I am a recovering people-pleaser now, and I’d dare to say I’m a Boundary Queen these days.  And there’s more: I know how to help, how to make change possible.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Dr. Becky Kennedy | Parenting on July 14, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'PARENTING Paradox The more you seek approval for your boundaries, the weaker your boundaries become. Swipe for more on how to set firm boundaries.'.

node.text:
I love boundaries.  I really do.

I didn’t used to love boundaries - in fact, I am a reformed people-pleaser. 

Were you a “good” kid or the “peacemaker” in your home? These labels seem harmless but when we look deeper, they often mean this: being so attuned to what others want and need that you distance yourself from your own wants and needs to keep the family system balanced.  You are more oriented toward what people want of you, not what you want for yourself. 

And how does all of this relate to boundaries? Boundaries are a way to protect your wants and needs and to protect wants and needs, your wants and needs have to be safe to recognize.  Any kid who played the role of “easy” or “good” kid learned that their own wants and needs were actually a threat - to closeness, peacefulness, security, and love. No wonder setting and holding boundaries are hard for so many of us - our bodies are understandably hesitant to give up the adaptations that were initially put in place to protect us. 

And then, as adults, this happens: when we continually struggle to hold boundaries, we get depleted and resentful. These feelings build up and then comes the rage.  The reactivity. The screaming. The “I can’t take it anymore!” This is a common cycle - and a reversible one. And it starts by learning how to set and hold boundaries. Everything changes from here.

Deep breaths.  You’re a good parent.  I know it.  And here’s the best news: We can change.  We can re-wire. It is NOT too late to learn to recognize your needs and wants and then to protect them by learning how to set AND hold boundaries.

This is why I’m so excited to share my upcoming workshop on Friday July 16: Setting Boundaries, Reducing Parenting Rage.

75 minutes, teaching + interactive Q & A, lots of immediately actionable strategies. And it’ll be recorded so if you can’t come live, you can still watch the entire thing (and you can watch over and over again). 

Please do share the second slide of this post with your community - lets come together and continue to build this movement - a team of boundary setting adults who start to take care of of themselves as we also take care of others.

node.text:
What do you do when your child pretends to have a gun?

First, take a deep breath. There's nothing wrong with your child, and this doesn't mean they want to harm anyone. Young kids often go through a phase of pretending to have weapons as a way of exploring big ideas like good and bad, power, control, and more. 

In this Deep Dive episode, I talk with parents Nina (@balkanina) and Tom, whose three-year-old recently pointed his finger at them and said "Pish! Pish!" I explain what's going on underneath pretend gun play, and model actionable strategies and scripts for responding in the moment. 

We also discuss how to navigate delicate conversations around gun safety with kids, and why it's important to differentiate between pretend guns and real guns.

Listen, subscribe, and write an honest review of the podcast for the chance to send in any question you have and receive a personalized video message from me in response! The winners for this week’s podcast review challenge are… Nicole-mom-of-boys and coachmoy! If this is you, please send and email to Goodinsidepodcast@gmail.com with the subject line “Podcast review winner” and any question on your mind.

node.text:
.
.
Tell me if this cycle feels familiar to you: you want to set a boundary - maybe it’s saying no to family wanting to visit or telling your kids you can’t host a playdate at your house… but instead of setting this boundary, you hear yourself saying yes. Then the resentment kicks in, either right away or later on.  Then a small thing set you off and there’s the reactivity, screaming, and rage.  Now let me be clear: there’s nothing wrong with you and I know this cycle isn’t enjoyable or intentional for any of us. 

And here’s the good news: this Boundary Struggle / Resentment / Rage cycle is *not* inevitable.  We can change it. And the change starts here: working on boundaries.

And here’s the even better news: Friday July 16 at 1230pm EST, I am holding a Zoom workshop that’ll give you concrete, actionable tools to change.  In Strengthening Boundaries, Reducing Parental Rage, I will teach you how to: set boundaries, tolerate pushback, cope with other’s disappointment, manage your own self-doubt, and develop consistency and self-assurance.

And maybe the best news: a ticket gives you access to the live workshop AND the recording. So if you can’t make it or might have to hop out early, no worries - the workshop will be there for you to watch over and over.

This is an important one.  Boundaries set us up for self-care, sturdy leadership, and the potential for relationships to actually feel enhancing and energizing, not depleting and enraging.

Don’t miss this workshop. It’s gonna be a good one. Link in bio or go to learning.goodinside.com

Be mindful of words like defiant, manipulative, oppositional. Swipe for an example of how our perspective determines our response'.

node.text:
You ask your child to stay in her room while you put your younger one to bed.  He comes out over and over, making noise in the hallway. What’s happening here? If your child being defiant? Disobedient? Or is your child having a hard time? Missing a skill? 

Here’s the point: how we label a situation determines how we intervene. 

If I see my child as defiant,I feel angry and disrespected. I’m likely to yell at my child and then punish him. Whats happening here? Well, ironically, I’ve just further cemented my older child’s role as the “bad kid,” I’ve increased resentment and frustration for me and my child, and any feelings or urges that were the basis of this behavior are still unseen and alone in my child and now my child is only more likely to act out in this or similar situations. Not. So. Effective.

And an alternative perspective? Well, it often starts with *not knowing* but instead with being curious: “I wonder what is going on for my child when I am putting his younger brother to bed? I know my child is GOOD INSIDE and so what would lead to him being so disruptive during his brother’s bedtime routine? I know my child knows how to be quiet… I know he understands, logically, my request… so something big must be getting in the way of that… hm…”

Now what happens, well, it’s kind of amazing because I’m leading with my curiosity, I may think about my child’s jealousy for the alone time his sibling has. I may think about my child’s struggle, in general, with delayed gratification or a difficulty entertaining himself when alone. Perhaps my child is scared to be in his room alone at night waiting for me. Now none of these thoughts make the behavior “ok.” What they do is allow me to look into the source of the behavior - and this is key to be effective in helping to change the behavior and preserve both my relationship with  my child and my child’s sense of himself as a good kid. Talk about bang for your buck.

Main point: Let’s spend today focused less on strategies for our kids and more on noticing the labels and frameworks we use. In my story today, I turn this idea into a manageable actionable challenge - check it out and join me!

HOW A PARENT FEELS: Disrespected WHAT A PARENT DOES: Punish GOOD INSIDE FRAMEWORK: "My child must have wanted something so badly and couldn't regulate that urge." HOW A PARENT FEELS: Empathetic WHAT A PARENT DOES: Cools down; then does a dry run with child of a similar situation to practice the coping skills needed to manage strong urges'.

node.text:
A few years ago, I lost my cell phone.

While pushing my child, I had put my phone on the top of the stroller, in a fold where it angled back. It must have fallen out along the way; I never heard it hit the sidewalk, and by the time I realized, it was too late.

I was so upset. I cried, I felt horrible, I wanted to rage. Clearly, putting my phone on the top of the stroller was an awful idea. I knew that.

Ok, stay with me, let’s fast forward a few years, and then we will return to my lost cell phone story.

My three-and-a-half year old son has a bowl of cheerios on the table and the bowl is too close to the edge. Before I can shift it a bit, he bumps his elbow into it; the bowl and cheerios fall all over the floor. He collapses into a puddle of tears.

I could say so many things: “This is why we need to be careful!” or “Why would you put the bowl so close to the edge?”

Instead, my body remembers that day with my lost cell phone.

I get to my son’s eye level and said to him, “You didn’t want that to happen, huh. You really didn't want that to fall. Ugh, that is the worst.” He softened and melted into me saying through tears, “No... I didn't want... that to happen.” He cried for a bit longer. Then he started picking up the Cheerios, and I joined him.

If I go back to that day when I lost my phone, I think about how bad it would have felt to hear “This is why you need to be careful!” or “Why would you put your phone on top of the stroller?” How if these words were uttered to me in the moment of my mistake, they would have inflamed me.

What would I have wanted to hear from someone? “You didn't want that to happen. You didn't want to lose your phone. Ugh, that is the worst.”

Try out these words to your child today: "You didn't want that to happen."
See how they feel to say and see how your child receives them. Maybe try them out with your partner, work colleague, or friend.

And perhaps, actually, start ... with yourself: after a mistake or when something doesn't go the way you would have wanted it to, place your hand on your heart and tell yourself, “I didn’t want that to happen. I really didn’t.”
